SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Confederate flag to come down in SC
The flag didn't fly over the Capital until 1961 in defiance of the Civil Rights movement. In 2000 the reason was changed to 'honor fallen confederate soldiers' and the flag was moved to a monument.
The sissies were defeated. Why would anyone want to show such a flag. Dumb!
The flag didn't fly over the Capital until 1961 in defiance of the Civil Rights movement. In 2000 the reason was changed to 'honor fallen confederate soldiers' and the flag was moved to a monument.

SC gives 2 reasons for the flag in 1961. First was the 100th anniversary of the Civil War. 2nd in defiance of the Civil Rights movement. Other states sent representatives to the ceremony who were black, and they were denied entrance because SC was still very segregated.
Interestingly, South Carolina at the time addressed the question of what the Civil Was was about too...

<i>In fact, the 169 men who formed the South Carolina Secession Convention all supported slavery and acknowledged in their "Declaration of the Immediate Causes Which Induce and Justify the Secession of South Carolina from the Federal Union" <b>that slavery was the central issue.<b><i>
The sissies were defeated. Why would anyone want to show such a flag. Dumb

Despite your obvious firm grasp on history, I hope you realize the "sissies" didnt put the flag on the SC State House grounds. That was done much, much later by self serving politicians, not soldiers. To disparage soldiers in such a way is contemptible. The British soldiers that we fought in the Revolutionary War weren't "sissies." Neither were the Spanish soldiers, the Native Americans of the Great Plains, the Germans, the Vietnamese...the list goes on and on. All of them displayed a courage that I'm guessing you will never have.
It's a little disturbing that you use your 12th post to state such drivel. Here's to better luck and clearer thinking on your later posts.

From Wikipedia arcticle on Union General William Tecumseh Sherman

''Sherman was not an abolitionist <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States" target="_blank">abolitionist</a> before the war and, like others of his time and background, he did not believe in "Negro equality." Before the war, Sherman at times even expressed some sympathy with the view of Southern whites that the black race was benefiting from slavery, although he opposed breaking up slave families and advocated teaching slaves to read and write. During the Civil War, Sherman declined to employ black troops in his armies.''
